in many of the world's navies. A tally, an inscribed black silk ribbon, is tied
around the base which usually bears the name of a ship or a navy. The cap may be
further embellished with a badge, cockade or other accessory. Visorless caps of
this kind began to be worn in the mid 19th century.

The more rigid type of sailor hat with a wide, flat peak is also known as square
rig (this refers generally to a type of sailor uniform) cap or pork pie (not to
be confused with the brimmed pork pie hat).

Sailor cap was first introduced in 1811 as a part of the uniform in the Russian

U.S. Navy and Bolivarian Armada of Venezuela sailors wear a unique white canvas
hat with an upright brim, often referred to as a "Dixie cup" in reference to its
similarity to the shape of a common disposable drinking cup,{cn} or a "gob hat"
